questions.text: The muscle shown in the following diagram is which type of muscle?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Parallel muscle fibers are found in biceps brachii. Option B-Spiral muscle fibers are found in pectoralis major as shown in figure. Option C-Multipennate muscle fibers are found in deltoid. Option D-Strap muscles are the infrahyoid muscles.for example:-sternohyoid,sternothyroid.

choices.text: Superior tarsal muscle consists of smooth muscle fibres
Venous sinuses lie between endosteal and meningeal layer of dura mater
Preganglionic autonomic axons from Edinger-Westphal nucleus travel via nerve to superior oblique to the ciliary ganglion
There is no preganglionic autonomic output from cervical spinal cord

questions.text: All of the following are true except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Superior tarsal muscle, also called as muller muscle consists of smooth muscle fibres, hence it is supplied by autonomic nervous system. Option B-Venous sinuses lie between endosteal and meningeal layer of dura mater is a true statement. Option C-The preganglionic autonomic axons from edinger westphal nucleus travel via nerve to inferior oblique to the ciliary ganglion. Option D-There is no preganglionic autonomic output from cervical spinal cord as lateral horn is present from T1-L1/2.

questions.text: Which of the following is caused due to obstruction of PICA-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Obstruction to PICA can lead to Wallenberg syndrome but M/C artery causing Wallenberg syndrome will be vertebral artery. Option B-Medial medullary syndrome occurs due to anterior spinal artery obstruction. Option C-Brown Sequard syndrome occurs due to hemisection of spinal cord. Option D-Cerebellar atrophy can occur due to PICA obstruction but other cerebellar arteries can compensate hence,wallenburg syndrome is a better answer here.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in brown Sequard syndrome?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Brown sequard syndrome is characterised by involvement of- • Spino thalamic tract= loss of pain and temperature on contralateral side. • dorsal column = Ipsilateral loss of fine sensations(vibration and position). • Cortico spinal tract= Ipsilateral spastic palsy below the lesion. • Spinal nerve = ipsilateral flaccid palsy at the level of lesion.

questions.text: Broca’s area is present in which part of the brain?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Angular gyrus is present in inferior parietal lobule. Option B-wernicke's area is present in Superior temporal gyrus. Option C-Broca's area is present inferior frontal gyrus. Option D-Superior frontal gyrus helps in higher cognitive functions.

choices.text: Ureteric bud and metanephric blastema gives rise to kidney

questions.text: Which of the following is true about urogenital development?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Urethra develops from urogenital sinus. Option B-Bladder develops from urogenital sinus. Option C-Ureteric bud and metanephric blastema gives rise to kidney. Option D-All are true all are true statement.

questions.text: The nerve associated with the pharyngeal cleft is derived from-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The nerves from pharyngeal arches and clefts are derived from neural crest cells. Option B-Endoderm forms lining of pharyngeal pouches. Option C-Mesoderm forms substance of pharyngeal arches. Option D-Notochord gives rise to apical ligament of dens and nucleus pulposus.

choices.text: Has a special connective tissue called Wharton's jelly
Has two veins and one artery
Most common defect is absence of one vein

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Umbilical Cord-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Umbilical Cord Has a special connective tissue called Wharton's jelly. Option B-Umbilical Cord has two arteries and one vein. Option C-.Most common defect is presence of one umbilical artery. Option D-Umbilical artery carries deoxygenated blood.

questions.text: Which of the following nerve marked in the image is thickened in leprosy-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Suboccipital nerve runs in suboccipital region which is present on posterior aspect of neck. Option B-The nerve shown is coming from the posterior triangle and approaching lower part of pinna,therefore it is the greater auricular nerve. Option C-Facial nerve emerges from anterior border of parotid gland and divides into 5 branches. Option D-Trigeminal nerve divides into three divisions i.e,ophthalmic,maxillary and mandibular.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a derivative of dorsal mesentery:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-lesser sac is not a derivative a dorsal mesentry.lesser sac is a cavity formed due to rotation of stomach. Option B,C,D-Greater omentum,Lienorenal ligament,Gastro splenic ligament are the derivatives of dorsal mesentery.

questions.text: Lacrimation is lost in lesion of?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Nasociliary nerve is a sensory nerve and supplies areas like tip of nose. Option B-Nerve concerned with lacrimation is greater petrosal nerve,therefore,Lacrimation is lost in lesion of Greater petrosal nerve. Option C-Anterior Ethmoidal nerve supplies lateral wall of nose and nasal septum. Option D-Supraorbital nerve supplies skin of scalp.

questions.text: The following marked muscle causes-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Abduction is caused by Abductor pollicis brevis and longus. Option B-The following marked muscle is adductor pollicis,hence it will take part in adduction. Option C-Flexion is caused by flexor pollicis brevis and longus. Option D-Extension is caused by extensor pollicis longus and brevis.

questions.text: First heart beat in a foetus occurs at how many days
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The first heart beat in a fetus occurs at 21-22 days.

choices.text: Middle layer is attached to the tips of transverse processes of lumbar vertebrae
Anterior layer covers the posterior surface of quadratus lumborum
It gives attachment to internal oblique and Transversus abdominis
Lateral arcuate ligament is derived from anterior layer of thoracolumbar fascia

questions.text: All of the following are true about thoracolumbar fascia except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Middle layer of thoracolumbar fascia is attached to the tips of transverse processes of lumbar vertebrae. Option B-Anterior layer covers the anterior surface of quadratus lumborum. Option C-Thoracolumbar fascia gives attachment to internal oblique and Transversus abdominis. Option D-Lateral arcuate ligament is derived from anterior layer of thoracolumbar fascia.

choices.text: Non-keratinised squamous with submucosa and minor salivary glands
Non-keratinised squamous without submucosa and minor salivary glands

questions.text: True about epithelium lining hard palate is-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hard palate is made of keratinized squamous epithelium.

questions.text: In aorta opening all are present except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) In aorta opening structures present are (Mnemonic = ATA) = Option A-A - azygous vein Option B-T - thoracic duct Option C-A - aorta. Option D-The vagus will pass through oesophageal opening.

questions.text: 7th and 8th ribs are attached to each other by which type of joint-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Synovial Ribs are a type of synovial type of joints as they have to support respiratory movements. Option B-Fibrous joint is present at suture line. Option C-Fibrocartilaginous joint is another name for symphysis. Option D-Symphysis joint is present in midline(Ex-pubic symphysis).

choices.text: It is muscular in neonates and children
Continuous above with the posterior layer of thoracolumbar fascia
Attached to transverse process of lower 2 lumbar vertebrae
Lower part extends upto the posterior iliopectineal line

questions.text: All of the following are true about Iliolumbar ligament except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-It is muscular in neonates and children is a true statement. Option B-The iliolumbar ligament is superiorly continuous with the anterior and middle layers of the thoracolumbar fascia. Option C- Iliolumbar ligament is attached to transverse process of lower 2 lumbar vertebrae. Option D-It's lower part extends upto the posterior iliopectineal line.

questions.text: Regarding Sibson’s fascia all are true except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Sibson’s fascia is Attached to cervical pleura present on apex of lung. Option B-Sibson’s fascia develops from scalenus minimumus. Option C-Subclavian vein arches over Sibson’s fascia. Option D-It is attached superiorly to seventh cervical vertebra.

questions.text: Special visceral efferent doesn’t have which of the following
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A,B,C-Nucleus ambiguous (9, 10, 11) and motor nucleus of 5th and 7th are known as special visceral efferent as they supplies the pharyngeal arches. Option D-Dorsal nucleus of 10th Nerve is parasympathetic component,hence it comes under general visceral efferent.

questions.text: Structure derived from 1st pharyngeal arch
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Levator palatini is a muscle of palate derived from 4th pharyngeal arch. Option B-Buccinator is a muscle of facial expression derived from 2nd pharyngeal arch. Option C-Stylohyoid is supplied by facial nerve,hence derived from 2nd pharyngeal arch. Option D-Anterior belly of digastric is supplied by mandibular nerve,so it is derived from 1st pharyngeal arch.

questions.text: Joint involved in movement of head left to right is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Joint involved in movement of head left to right is Atlantoaxial joint,also known as "No joint". Option B-Atlanto occipital is also known as "yes joint" Option C,D-C2 – C3 and C3 – C4 have plane synovial joint between articular facets of vertebrae.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of Parotid gland
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Auriculotemporal nerve Pathway :- 9th Nerve -> Jacobson plexus -> tympanic plexus ->lesser petrosal Nerve-> comes out of foramen ovale (along with mandibular nerve) -> relay in otic ganglion> Auriculo-temporal nerve. Option B-Lingual nerve is associated with submandibular ganglion. Option C-Glossopharyngeal nerve supplies stylopharyngeus. Option D-Inferior alveolar nerve supplies lower alveolar sockets.

questions.text: Right coronary artery arises from
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Right coronary artery arises from anterior aortic sinus. Option B-Posterior aortic sinus on left side gives rise to left coronary artery. Option C,D-Anterior and Posterior coronary sinus do not give rise to any coronary arteries.

questions.text: Which nerve passes through the marked foramen in the given image
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Lingual nerve is a branch of posterior division of mandibular nerve which supplies anterior 2/3rd of tongue. Option B-Mandibular nerve comes out of foramen ovale. Option C-Chorda tympani nerve joins lingual nerve and supplies anterior 2/3rd of tongue. Option D-Inferior alveolar nerve passes through the marked foramen i.e,mandibular foramen and travels through the bone and emerge out of mental foramen as mental nerve..

questions.text: Identify the marked muscle in the diagram
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Brachioradialis runs on radial side of forearm and attaches on radius i.e, it do not cross carpals. Option B-The marked muscle is just crossing the Carpal region and it is present on the same Side as thumb (radial region) therefore,it is extension carpi radialis longus . Option C-Flexor carpi radialis is present in flexor compartment and attaches on carpal bones on radial side. Option D-Extensor carpi ulnaris crosses the Carpal region and it is present on the ulnar side.

questions.text: Ducts of bellini are present in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Pancreas contains centriacinar cells. Option B-Liver has space of disse. Option C-Duct of Bellini are distal collecting duct and are present in kidney. Option D-Salivary gland contains striated ducts.

questions.text: Which nerve supplies the marked area
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Ulnar nerve supplies medial two and a half fingers on dorsal side and one and a half fingers on ventral side. Option B-Median nerve supplies lateral three and a half fingers on ventral side. Option C-The radial nerve supplies the marked area,which is lateral two and a half fingers on dorsal side. Option D-Posterior interosseus nerve is purely motor nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a boundary of calot’s triangle
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Boundaries of Calots triangle are:- Option A- common hepatic duct Option B-Cystic duct Option C-Inferior surface of liver Option D-Gall bladder is not a boundary of calot’s triangle.

questions.text: Marked area in the given image is supplied by which dermatome?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The marked structure is umbilicus and is present at T10 level.

questions.text: Identify the type of fibres marked in the image
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Projection fibers:-projection Fibers are Passing to and from the brainstem to the entire cerebral cortex eg = subcortical - internal capsule. Option B,C-Association fibers :-Association fibers connect different areas in one hemisphere.eg -arcuate fasciculus Option D-Commissural fibers:-Commissure fibers connect corresponding regions of the two hemispheres.eg- corpus callosum

questions.text: Identify the structure marked by red arrow in given image
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-The great cerebral vein is one of the large blood vessels in the skull draining the cerebrum of the brain. Option B-Pineal gland is located in posterior wall of 3rd ventricle. Option C-The fornix is a C-shaped bundle of white matter that is found in the mesial aspect of the cerebral hemispheres, below the corpus callosum. The fornix is an important part of the limbic system, and represents the largest single pathway of the hippocampus, connecting it to various subcortical structures. Option D-Falx cerebri is a dural fold situated in midline.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the marked structure in the given image
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A,B-Anterior and posterior interosseous nerve do not supply lumbricals. Option C-lumbrical 3 & 4 are bipinnate and are supplied by ulnar nerve. Option D-Marked structures are lumbricals.lumbrical I & 2 are unipinnate and are supplied by median nerve.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the given image.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Cerebrum is present above the cerebellum. Option B-Brainstem is located in front of cerebellum. Option C-Corpus callosum connects two cerebral hemispheres. Option D-The marked structure in the given picture is cerebellum.

questions.text: Nerve injured in frey’s syndrome is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Frey syndrome usually occurs with auriculotemporal nerve injury caused by surgical intervention or trauma in the parotid region, The auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the trigeminal nerve, consists of parasympathetic fibers that signal the parotid gland to produce saliva and sympathetic fibers that innervate the sweat glands of the face and scalp. When an insult to the parasympathetic and sympathetic nerve fibers of the auriculotemporal nerve in the parotid region occurs, the resulting aberrant regeneration of post-ganglionic parasympathetic nerve fibers (responsible for salivary secretion) along the pre-existing sympathetic pathways to the vessels and sweat glands of the skin leads to the development of Frey syndrome. Patients with Frey syndrome often present with facial warmth, flushing, and sweating in the territory of the auriculotemporal nerve overlying the parotid gland, which may include the preauricular skin, the temporal skin, the scalp, and the temporomandibular joint region. Symptoms occur during meals, especially with spicy and sour foods.

questions.text: Contralateral loss of pain and temperature is due to lesion in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-anterior spinothalamic tract carries touch, pressure. Option B-lateral spinothalamic tract carries pain and temperature. Option C,D-Fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus [dorsal column tract] carries fine sensations like fine touch,vibration,proprioception.

questions.text: Space of disse is seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Spleen has red and white pulp. Option B-Lymph node has subcapsular sinus. Option C-space of disse is seen in liver. Option D-Bone shows trabeculations.

questions.text: The nerve that supplies the marked structure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The marked structure is levator scapulae muscle which is supplied by dorsal scapular nerve [arises from C5 root]. Option B-Suprascapular nerve supplies supraspinatus and infraspinatus. Option C-Dorsal rami of C1 supplies muscles of back. Option D-Subscapular nerve supplies subscapularis.

questions.text: Upward extension of thyroid swelling is prevented by which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Thyroid grand is enclosed in big peritracheal fascia,which prevents Upward extension of thyroid swelling. Option B-The Ligament of Berry is a dense condensation of pre-tracheal vascular fascia that attaches the thyroid to the crico-tracheal structures posteriorly. Option C-Thyrohyoid membrane is present between lower border of hyoid and upper border of thyroid cartilage. Option D-Sterno thyroid attaches at oblique line of lamina of thyroid cartilage.

questions.text: Identify the type of joint in the given image:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Syndesmoses are found between the bones of the forearm (radius and ulna) and the leg (tibia and fibula). Option B-Synarthrosis is an immovably fixed joint between bones connected by fibrous tissue (for example, the sutures of the skull). Option C-At a synchondrosis, the bones are united by hyaline cartilage. The epiphyseal plate of growing long bones and the first sternocostal joint that unites the first rib to the sternum are examples of synchondroses. Option D-In the the image,costotransverse and costovertebral joints are shown, and both are types of synovial joints .

questions.text: A patient presents with clinical features of Ataxia, vertigo. The following condition is due to thrombosis in which artery?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Posterior cerebral artery thrombosis can lead to heteronymous hemianopia with macular sparing. Option B-Middle cerebral artery thrombosis can lead to broca's and wernicke's aphasia. Option C-Internal carotid artery itself divides into anetrior and Middle cerebral artery. Option D-In ataxia and vertigo, cerebellum is involved and the only cerebellar artery mentioned in options is superior cerebellar artery.

questions.text: The reason for the long course of left recurrent laryngeal Nerve is d/t the persistence of which aortic arch artery?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Derivatives of aortic arch:- Arch I - maxillary arteries Arch 2 - hyoid and stapedial arteries Arch 3 - common carotid, and first part of internal carotid arteries Arch 4 -(Left side) - arch of aorta from left common carotid to Left subclavian artery. (Right. side) = right subclavian artery (proximal portion): Arch 6 (left side) - Left pulmonary artery and ductus arteriosus (right side)- right pulmonary artery. The recurrent laryngeal nerve is a branch of vagus nerve. On the left side, ductus arteriosus is present (6th arch) , So left recurrent laryngeal nerve has to loop around it to cross it where as right recurrent laryngeal nerve can pass straight and doesn’t need to loop around as ductus arteriosus is absent on the right side This the reason for longer course of left recurrent laryngeal nerve.

questions.text: A patient presented with the extension of the MCP joint and flexion of IP. Which muscle is affected?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Extensor digitorum performs Extension of MCP,IP and wrist joint. Option B-Abductor pollicis brevis does abduction at thumb. Option C-Interossei and lumbricals perform the action of flexion at MCP joint and extension at IP joint.therefore,in cases of palsy of Interossei and lumbricals,patient will present with the extension of the MCP joint and flexion of IP joint. Option D-Abductor pollicis longus also does abduction at thumb..

choices.text: Right Gastric and Right gastroepiploic artery
Right Gastric and Left gastric artery
Right Gastroepiploic and Left short gastric vessels
Right Gastric and short gastric vessels

questions.text: Ligation of the common hepatic artery will impair blood supply in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-if common hepatic artery ligated,blood supply in Right gastric and right gastro epiploic artery will impaired as right gastric artery is a branch of proper hepatic artery which itself is a branch of common hepatic artery.And right gastroepiploic artery is a branch of gastroduodenal artery which itself is a branch of common hepatic artery. Option B-Left gastric artery is a direct branch of celiac trunk. Option C,D-short gastric vessels are branches of splenic artery.

questions.text: A patient presented with weakness of the right side of the face with loss of pain and temperature. Pain and temperature sensation of the left leg is lost. The lesion is most likely located in?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) weakness of the right side of the face-due to involvement of right side facial nerve. loss of pain and temperature of the right side of the face-due to involvement of right side trigeminal nucleus. Pain and temperature sensation of the left leg is lost-due to involvement of right side spinal lemniscus. These three right side facial nerve,right side trigeminal nucleus and right side spinal lemniscus are together located in lateral pons. hence,The lseion is located in lateral pons.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Molecular layer has basket and stellate cells. Option B-In the images cerebellum is shown and The marked structures are purkinje cells. Option C,D-granular cells and Golgi cells are located in granular layer.

questions.text: Structure injured in submandibular gland excision:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Inferior alveolar nerve enters tha mandibular foramen and runs within mandibular canal. Option B-W.r.t submandibular gland- we have a nerve looping around (Mnemonic:- L-lingual & L- loop) and another nerve (not looping) present beside it is hypoglossal nerve. When we are operating in this area, both these nerves are at high risk of injury. Option C-Glossopharyngeal nerve lies wall away from submandibular gland. Option D-Facial nerve is injured during parotid surgeries.

questions.text: Patient is brought to emergency after road traffic accident with multiple fractures of humerus. On examination he is unable to flex and supinate forearm. Also there is loss of sensations on lateral aspect of forearm. Which of the following Nerve is injured?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Ulnar nerve supplies skin of medial side of forearm. Option B-Median supplies skin of palm. Option C-Radial nerve supplies skin of dorsum of hand. Option D-flexion and supination of forearm is done by biceps,which is siupplied by musculocutaneous nerve.Also musculocutaneous nerve continues as lateral cutaneous nerve of forearm and supplies the skin of that side.Hence,unable to flex and supinate the forearm along with loss of sensation on lateral aspect of forearm indicates that the nerve injured is musculocutaneous nerve.

questions.text: Downward enlargement of spleen is prevented by?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Lienorenal ligament connects spleen with left kidney but it do not prevents downward enlargement of spleen. Option B-Phrenicocolic ligament aka sustentaculum lienis (sustentaculum= Support and Lienis= means spleen) so it is prevents downward enlargement of spleen. Option C-Head of pancreas doesn't lies in contact with spleen. Option D-Left renal artery also doesn't lies in contact with spleen.

questions.text: Nerve damaged when shunt is placed using great saphenous vein is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Deep Peroneal Nerve injury leads to foot drop. Option B-Superficial Peroneal Nerve injury leads to loss of eversion of foot. Option C-when a shunt is placed using great saphenous vein - saphenous nerve is at a high risk of injury as it runs along with it. Option D-Sural Nerve runs along with short saphenous vein.

questions.text: A Patient presents after Fracture at skull base and Doctor examined the marked area. Which nerve supplies the marked muscle and is involved in Gag reflex
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) X N. (Vagus Nerve).Explanation: The red arrow in the image points to the pharynx, which contains muscles essential for swallowing and the gag reflex. The gag reflex is a protective reflex with both a sensory (afferent) limb and a motor (efferent) limb. While the Glossopharyngeal nerve (IX N.) provides the primary sensory input from the pharynx, the Vagus nerve (X N.) is the main motor nerve that supplies most of the muscles of the pharynx, including the pharyngeal constrictors and palatal muscles responsible for the reflexive contractions seen in the gag reflex. Therefore, the Vagus nerve directly "supplies the marked muscle" (pharyngeal muscles) and executes the motor component of the gag reflex. Therefore, the answer is 10th nerve i.e,vagus nerve

questions.text: Aneurysm of which artery causes visual defects by compressing at optic chiasma ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A,B,C-Anterior cerebral,Middle cerebral and Anterior Choroidal do not usually cause compression at optic chiasma. Option D-Anterior communicating artery is locared near optic chiasma hence,Aneurysm of Anterior communicating artery causes visual defects by compressing at optic chiasma.if the compression is at the level of optics chiasma, it will cause bitemporal hemianopia.

questions.text: A Patient is admitted with diagnosis of Meningitis. Lumbar puncture was done to evaluate. Which is the last Layer to be Pierced in this procedure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Structures pierced during lumbar puncture - from outside to inside are:- 1. skin 2. sub cutaneous tissue 3. supraspinous ligament 4. interspinous ligament 5. Ligamentum flavum 6. dura 7. arachnoid

questions.text: Which of the following papilla is marked in the given picture?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Foliate papillae are small sized vertical folds located on the tongue's posterolateral sides, just anterior to the palatoglossal arch of fauces. Four or five in number, they are found in the lingual mucosa and have a covering layer of non-keratinized epithelium. Option B-Filiform papillae are abundant, conical in shape with the vertex pointed caudally, and are located on the rostral, dorsal, and lateral surfaces of the tongue. Option C-The dorsal surfaces of fungiform papillae have a single taste bud. Fungiform papillae are found on the dorsal rostral surface of the tongue. Option D-In the image,circumvallate papillae are shown. The very large circumvallate papillae reside at the base of your tongue near your throat and contain hundreds of taste buds. These papillae are so large they are visible to the naked eye.They have a cleft like space on both sides.

questions.text: Testing of thumb was done as shown in the picture. Which of the following nerve supplies the muscle being tested here.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) This is pen test to check abductor pollicis brevis We ask the patient to outstretch hand and then touch tip of the pen with the tip of the thumb. Therefore, it is used to assess median nerve.

questions.text: Ligament derived from the marked structure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Cranial part of dorsal mesogastrium forms Gastro phrenic ligament, and Caudal part is greater omentum. Option B-Phrenicocolic Ligament lies between diaphragm and colon. Option C-Ligament between body wall and liver is falciform ligament. Ligament between liver and stomach -gastrohepatic ligament (Lesser omentum) and ligament between stomach and spleen is Gastro splenic ligament. Option D-ligament in the behind,between the spleen and kidneys is Leinorenal ligament ( Because kidneys are present posteriorly ).

questions.text: A patient presents with drooping of angle of mouth and inability to blow. Which of the following nerve is involved in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-3rd nerve palsy leads to weakness of extraocular muscles. Option B-5th nerve palsy leads to weakness of muscles of mastication. Option C-drooping of angle of mouth and inability to blow is seen in 7th nerve palsy (BELL’S PALSY). Option D-9th nerve palsy leads to weakness of stylopharyneus and absence of gag reflex.

questions.text: A patient with H/O pain in both legs while taking long walk. He has developed toe gangrene and he admits to have Erectile dysfunction. Which of the following artery is involved in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Right Internal Iliac Artery obstruction won't cause pain in both legs. Option B-Right External Iliac Artery obstruction will cause pain only in right leg. Option C-left External Iliac Artery obstruction will cause pain only in left leg. Option D-Aorto iliac Junction obstruction will cause pain in both legs while taking long walk [intermittent claudication], toe gangrene and Erectile dysfunction due to reduced penile blood supply. Internal iliac artery gives two branches known as anterior division & posterior division. ANTERIOR DIVISION Mnemonic – shiv obtained marks in PG S (V) – superior Vesicle I (V) – inferior vesicle (replaced in females by uterine & vaginal a. ) OBTAINED – obturator MARKS – middle rectal IN (P)- inf pudendal (G)- inf gluteal POSTERIOR DIVISION – Mnemonic – SIL S – Sup. gluteal I – Ilio lumbar L – lat. Sacral

questions.text: A Patient presents with Ballistic involuntary movements. Which of the following is responsible?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Caudate Nucleus lesion leads to chorea. Option B-Thalamus lesion leads to thalamic pain syndrome. Option C-Substantia Nigra lesion leads to parkinsonism. Option D-Ballistic movements are characteristic for hemiballismus,which occurs due to lesion in subthalamic nucleus.

questions.text: Given histology picture is of which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-ELASTIC CARTILAGE will have Big cells seen singly or in the form of the groups and long & short wavy fibers (known as elastic and collagen fibers ) present in between . Option B-In the Image Shown,There are parallel rows of nuclei and parallel fibers . Alternate rows of fibers and cells are present here.Therefore , it is FIBROCARTILAGE. Fibers contain both collagen type 1 & type 2 (i.e of both bone and cartilage). Option C,D-HYALINE CARTILAGE will have 1. Presence of perichondrium 2. Presence of cell nests 3. Absence of fibers in between the group of cells (cell nests ).

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the given Picture ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Important features of Islets of Langerhans:- • Size of islet will be very huge when compared with the surrounding acini. • On the inside blood capillaries are seen. Islet part is the endocrine part of pancreas(endocrine =ductless),therefore hormones are directly released into blood via capillaries. Option B-Lymphatic nodules are round aggregates of small, dark staining inactive (naïve) B lymphocytes, usually near the capsule, within a network of follicular dendritic cell processes. Option C-serous Demilunes are seen in sublingual glands. Option D-Glomeruli is seen in kidney with cut sections of tubules present in the surroundings.

questions.text: Identify the marked bone?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-The malleus is the 1st ossicle, attaching to and moving with the tympanic membrane. This ossicle has a head, neck, short process, and handle. Option B-The incus is the 2nd ossicle and has a body and short and long processes. This bone connects with the stapes and forms the incudostapedial joint. Option C-The stapes is the 3rd ossicle, consisting of a head, legs, and a footplate. This bone is the smallest in the human body. The stapes articulates with the inner ear's oval window. Option D-Talus is present in the foot.

questions.text: A patient complains of headache with periorbital pain, tearing/ lacrimation, drooling of saliva, jaw spasm/pain, with light and accommodation reflex normal and pupils neither dilated nor constricted. Features of the patient can be explained by the involvement of which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-A is the optic nerve but light and accommodation reflex are normal.so this nerve is not injured. Option B-B is oculomotor nerve but light and accommodation reflex are normal.so this nerve is not injured. Option C-C is trigeminal nerve which can result in headache with periorbital pain and jaw spasm/pain due to involvement of muscles of mastication. Option D-D is facial nerve but it do not cause jaw spasm/pain.

questions.text: A patient who underwent Varicose veins surgical treatment now presents with loss of sensation in medial leg. Which of the following nerve is injured in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Sural Nerve lies in close relation with short saphenous nerve. Option B-When we are dealing with varicose vein,there is a risk of damage of great saphenous vein along with sapheneous nerve which runs in close relation to it. Option C-Obturator Nerve exits via obturator foramen and supplies adductors of thigh. Option D-Plantar Nerve supplies plantar aspect of foot.

questions.text: A defect in which of the following forms the deep inguinal ring?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Internal oblique froms conjoint tendon. Option B-External oblique has an opening called deep inguinal ring. Option C-Parietal peritoneum forms processus vaginalis. Option D-The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the transversalis fascia present 1 cm above the inguinal ligament, midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic symphysis.

questions.text: A student had his jaw locked while yawning. Which of the following muscles is attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lateral pterygoid:- Origin- upper head of the Lateral pterygoid originates from the infratemporal surface and infratemporal crest of the greater wing of sphenoid bone. The lower head arises from the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate. Insertion- into the pterygoid fovea, the capsule of the temporomandibular joint and the articular disc. The action of the Lateral pterygoid is depression, protrusion and side to side movement of the jaw.

questions.text: Identify the structure in the following histological image-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The structure shown in the following histological image is Glomerulus is a rounded tuft of anastomosing capillaries lined by fenestrated endothelium. It is supported by the mesangium. Other options-

questions.text: Injury at which site causes failure of dorsiflexion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-A is lateral epicondyle of femur. Option B-B is head of fibula. Option C-The site marked as ‘C’ in the given X-ray is the neck of fibula. Injury at this site causes failure of dorsiflexion (foot drop), loss of toe extension and eversion of the foot due to injury to the common fibular nerve. Sensory innervation of the dorsum of the foot including the first web space is also lost. The CPN (L4, L5, S1, S2) curves laterally round the neck of fibula and gets divided into the superficial and deep fibular nerves. Option D-D is shaft of tibia.

questions.text: A defect in which of the following arches causes the defect shown in the image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-4th right aortic arch gives rise to the proximal part of the right Subclavian artery. Option B-4th left aortic arch gives rise to arch of aorta. Option C-6th right aortic arch forms the proximal part of the right pulmonary artery. Option D-The image shows a patent ductus arteriosus due to a defect in the left side of the 6th pharyngeal arch.

questions.text: Which of the following structures develops from the structure marked as A?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Medial Umbilical ligament forms from umbilical arteries. Option B-The structure marked is the Allantois. Its distal portion forms the urachus, which in turn gives rise to the median umbilical ligament. Option C-Meckels diverticulum is derived from vitellointestinal duct. Option D-Ligamentum teres is remnant of left umbilical vein.

choices.text: Left colic and middle colic veins
Esophageal veins and left gastric veins

questions.text: A patient comes with abdominal pain, jaundice, and portal hypertension. Anastomosis between which of the following veins is seen?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Left colic and middle colic veins are part of portal circulation. Option B-In the given scenario of portal hypertension [abdominal pain, jaundice], anastomosis between esophageal veins and left gastric veins can be seen. Option C-Superior rectal and phrenic veins do not anastomose with each other. Option D-Sigmoid and superior rectal veins are part of portal circulation.

choices.text: Investing layer of deep cervical fascia

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling under the left ear lobule and complains of pain. Which of the following structures is the likely cause of pain?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Facial nerve is associated with Hitzelberger sign which is the numbness of the posterosuperior meatal wall of the external auditory canal. It is seen in acoustic neuroma and is not associated with swelling over the parotid region. Option B-The greater auricular nerve provides sensory innervation to the skin overlying the parotid gland and ear lobule. Option C-The auriculotemporal nerve can cause referred pain due to caries tooth or ulcerative lesions of the oral cavity. However it is not the primary cause of pain in parotid region due to swelling. Option D-Investing layer of deep cervical fascia itself does not transmit pain sensation.

questions.text: A singer presents with difficulty in singing at high pitch. On examination bowing of vocal cord is seen on right side. Which of the following muscle has been compromised?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Posterior cricoarytenoid muscle palsy leads to adduction of vocal cords. Option B-Lateral cricoarytenoid muscle palsy leads to abduction of vocal cords. Option C-Cricothyroid palsy leads to difficulty in singing at high pitch. On examination bowing of vocal cord will be seen. Option D-Thyroarytenoid muscle palsy leads to abduction of vocal cords.

questions.text: An absent gag reflex can result from injury to which of the following nerves?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The gag reflex is a reflex contraction of the back of the throat, elicited by touching the posterior pharyngeal wall, tonsillar area, or the base of the tongue. Stimulation results in a visible contraction of the pharyngeal wall. The gag reflex is a protective response that prevents oral contents from entering the throat except as part of normal swallowing and helps prevent choking. The afferent limb of the reflex is supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX), which inputs to the nucleus solitarius and the spinal trigeminal nucleus. The efferent limb is supplied by the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) from the nucleus ambiguus. All of these are located in the medulla. The lower cranial nerves are involved in pharyngeal and laryngeal function as well as in movements of the neck and tongue. Damage to them can result in problems with speech and swallowing.

questions.text: Ptosis in Horner syndrome is due to paralysis of which muscle
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Ptosis in Horner syndrome is due to paralysis of Muller muscle. Option B-Orbitalis covers the inferior orbital fissure. Option C-Orbicularis oculi helps in closure of eyelids. Option D-Sphincter pupillae helps in constriction of pupil.

choices.text: Loss of sensation in the mucosa of nasopharynx
Loss of sensation in maxillary area of face
Loss of sensation in jaw area
Loss of sensation on scalp and nose

questions.text: Which of the following is the clinical presentation, when the nerve passing through the arrow marked region has been lesioned?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Loss of sensation in the mucosa of nasopharynx occurs due to injury to nasopalatine nerve. Option B-Loss of sensation in maxillary area of face occurs due to injury to maxillary nerve,which exits via foramen rotundum. Option C-Loss of sensation in jaw area occurs due to injury to greater auricular nerve. Option D-Loss of sensation on scalp and nose occurs due to injury to ophthalmic branch of trigeminal nerve which exits via superior orbital fissure as shown in fissure.

questions.text: Find the correct matching for auricle nerve supply
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) A is Greater auricular nerve. B is Auriculotemporal nerve. C is Vagus nerve. D is Lesser occipital nerve.

questions.text: What will be the patient's features if there is a lesion in Brodmann area 22?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Expressive aphasia (also known as Broca's aphasia) is a type of aphasia characterized by partial loss of the ability to produce language (spoken, manual, or written), although comprehension generally remains intact. A person with expressive aphasia will exhibit effortful speech. Option B-Receptive aphasia is also known as fluent, sensory, or Wernicke aphasia. The patient cannot understand words or recognize symbols, whether they are auditory, tactile, or visual. This form is related to an abnormality of the posterosuperior temporal gyrus of the Wernicke area [area 22]. Option C-Poor repetition of language is seen in both broca's and wernicke's aphasia. Option D-Poor naming s seen in both broca's and wernicke's aphasia.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Bladder exstrophy is a rare condition present at birth. During pregnancy, the bladder of an unborn baby, also called a fetus, forms outside of the lower abdominal region. The exposed bladder can't store urine or work as it should. This causes the baby to leak urine after being born. Option B-An omphalocele is a birth defect in which an infant's intestine or other abdominal organs are outside of the body because of a hole in the belly button (navel) area. The intestines are covered only by a thin layer of tissue and can be easily seen. Option C-Gastroschisis is a condition where the intestines extend outside of the body through a hole beside the belly button. Surgery places the abdominal organs inside the baby's body and repair the hole. Option D-An umbilical hernia occurs at the umbilicus (belly button) when a loop of intestine pushes through the umbilical ring, a small opening in a fetus' abdominal muscles

questions.text: Fecal material coming out from umbilicus. The situation is due to persistence of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The vitelline duct acts as a communicating tract between the embryonic yolk sac and its primitive midgut during early human development.An umbilical fistula may form due to persistence of vitelline duct.In this situation,Fecal material comes out from umbilicus. Option B-Urachus develops into median umbilical ligament. Option C-Gastroschisis is a condition where the intestines extend outside of the body through a hole beside the belly button. Option D-An omphalocele is a birth defect in which an infant's intestine or other abdominal organs are outside of the body because of a hole in the belly button (navel) area. The intestines are covered only by a thin layer of tissue and can be easily seen.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the image shown below:-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Ileal diverticulum/Meckel diverticulum is a common congenital abnormality of the small intestine caused by incomplete obliteration of the vitelline (omphalomesenteric) duct. Most patients with Meckel diverticulum are asymptomatic, with the abnormality discovered only incidentally in imaging studies. Option B-A urachal cyst occurs when a pocket forms in a remnant of the urachus, between the bladder and the naval. This fluid-filled sac can vary in size and clinical presentation. Option C-Umbilical fistulae can occur when there is a failure of closure of the structures passing through the umbilicus. Option D-An omphalocele is a birth defect in which an infant's intestine or other abdominal organs are outside of the body because of a hole in the belly button (navel) area. The intestines are covered only by a thin layer of tissue and can be easily seen.

questions.text: The covering of an omphalocele is derived from which layer
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The covering of an omphalocele is derived from Amnion. An omphalocele is considered an abdominal wall defect (a hole in the abdominal wall). The child's intestines usually stick out (protrude) through the hole. The condition looks similar to gastroschisis. An omphalocele is a birth defect in which the infant's intestine or other abdominal organs protrude through a hole in the belly button area and are covered with a membrane. In gastroschisis, there is no covering membrane.

questions.text: Behind medial malleolus and in front of Achilles tendon, which artery is palpated
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Posterior tibial artery is palpated behind medial malleolus and in front of Achilles tendon. Option B-Peroneal artery is difficult to palpate. Option C-Anterior tibial artery is palpated anteriorly between two malleoli. Option D-Dorsalis pedis artery is palpated just lateral to extensor hallucis longus tendon.

questions.text: Doctor inverted the ankle against resistance and palpate a tendon behind medial malleolus
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Tibialis anterior is located anterior to medial malleolus. Option B-Tibialis posterior is located behind medial malleolus and can be palpated. Option C,D-Flexor digitorum and Flexor hallucis longus are also located behind medial malleolus but they are difficult to palpate.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with sciatica had tender hamstrings. Which of the following nerve supplies a hybrid muscle, which is partially spared in this patient
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Adductor magnus is a hybrid muscle as the adductor and hamstring portions of the muscle are innervated by two different nerves. The adductor portion is innervated by the posterior division of the obturator nerve while the hamstring portion is innervated by the sciatic nerve.

questions.text: Most common site of Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A,C-Hernia from Central tendon and Crural site are rare. Option B-Most common site of Congenital diaphragmatic hernia/Bochdalek hernia is Posterolateral diaphragm. Option D-Most common site of morgagni hernia is Anterolateral diaphragm.

questions.text: A patient presents with loss of sensation on lateral 3 &1/2 fingers and thenar atrophy. Which of the following nerve is involved?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Median nerve injury leads to loss of sensation on lateral 3 &1/2 fingers and thenar atrophy. Option B-Ulnar nerve injury leads to loss of sensation on medial 1 and 1/2 fingers and hypothenar atrophy. Option C-Radial nerve injury leads to wrist drop. Option D-Anterior interosseous nerve supplies to FPL,FDP and pronator quadratus.

questions.text: A man came to OPD who can't close button of his shirt and can't make O sign, which of the following muscle is paralysed.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A man who can't close button of his shirt and can't make O sign indicates palsy of Abductor pollicis brevis,supplied by median nerve. Abductor pollicis brevis muscle is the most lateral and superficial of the three muscles forming the thenar eminence. Origin It takes its origin from the front of transverse carpal ligament, extending into the tubercles of scaphoid and trapezium. Insertion The muscle has a short tendon which attaches to the radial side of the base of the proximal phalanx of the thumb.

questions.text: Identify the marked nerve (related to Pectoralis Minor)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Medial pectoral nerve pierces pectoralis minor as shown in figure. Option B-Lateral pectoral nerve pierces clavipectoral fascia. Option C-Long thoracic nerve lies on serratus anterior muscle. Option D-Thoracodorsal nerve lies posteriorly and supplies latissimus dorsi.

choices.text: Primary oocyte arrested in prophase - I
Primary oocyte arrested in prophase - II
Secondary oocyte arrested in prophase - II
Secondary oocyte arrested in metaphase - II

questions.text: Post ovulation the oocyte is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Before ovulation,the oocyte is Primary oocyte arrested in prophase - I Post ovulation, the oocyte is Secondary oocyte arrested in metaphase - II

questions.text: Fracture at which of the following site affects the longitudinal growth of a bone
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Fracture at Epiphyseal plate site affects the longitudinal growth of a bone. Option B-The diaphysis is the hollow, tubular shaft that runs between the proximal and distal ends of the bone. Option C-The wider section at each end of the bone is called the epiphysis. Option D-Each epiphysis meets the diaphysis at the metaphysis.

questions.text: Match the columns based on marked areas
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A-3, B-1, C-2, D-4

questions.text: A neonate has presented with failure to pass the meconium. The structure absent in the pathology lie in which of the following layers. Choose the correct answer.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) This is a case of Hirschsprung disease.It is a birth defect in which some nerve cells are missing in the large intestine, so a child’s intestine can’t move stool and becomes blocked. The nerve cells are located in Auerbach and meissner's plexus located in muscularis propria and submucosa respectively. Hence,from the given picture B and C are the answer. A-mucosa B-submucosa C-muscularis propria D-serosa.

questions.text: Which type of tongue papillae lacks taste buds
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Fungiform papillae are mushroom-shaped structures located on the dorsum of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.Due to their rich capillary network, larger size and patchy distribution, fungiform papillae can be identified as reddish dots that contrast to the smaller and more numerous filiform papillae. Option B-Filliform papillae lacks taste buds. Option C-The very large circumvallate papillae reside at the base of your tongue near your throat and contain hundreds of taste buds. Option D-The foliate papillae appear as a series of red colored, leaf–like ridges of mucosa. They are covered with epithelium, lack keratin and so are softer, and bear many taste buds.

questions.text: This type of epithelium is seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The given epithelium is transitional epithelium which is found in ureter. Option B-Trachea has pseudostratified columnar epithelium. Option C-Duodenum has simple columnar epithelium. Option D-Gall bladder has simple columnar epithelium.
